Simon,

>
> Try the JUnit FAQ. This entry might be a good place to start:
>=
 
> http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#tests_15
> 
> There are ma=
ny good pieces of information in the FAQ and I suggest
> reading it careful=
ly.
> 

Definitely, and started there first!  It gave me some really good 
=
pointers and make me rethink some of my strategy!

> 
> The best thing with=
 JUnit testing is to think in terms of 
behaviours.
> What behaviour are yo=
u expecting from your system and write a test 
for
> that. Do not let the f=
act that some behaviours span multiple objects
> while others use only a si=
ngle method cause you to lose sight of the
> fact that testing is best done=
 at the unit level and the most 
workable
> unit is the unit of behaviour.
=
> 

You make an excellent point, and something I didn't realize.  I was 
th=
inking unit testing as 'test each method of my class' and make sure 
they w=
ork as expected.  But really, I'm looking to test and see if my 
applicatio=
n functionality (behaviour) works.  "Can I create a report" 
is what I'm re=
ally after...

Thanks again.
